raQ1.title: Do you have a current overview of your IT risks (e.g., which systems are critical, where vulnerabilities exist)?
raQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires regular risk analyses (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. a NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 1 BSIG). BSI recommends the methodology from BSI Standard 200-3.
raQ1.help: An IT risk overview lists which systems are critical for your business and where vulnerabilities exist. This can be a simple spreadsheet, e.g.: 'Our ERP server runs on Windows Server 2012 — no more vendor support, high risk.' Without this overview, you don't know where to act first.

maturity.level0: No risk analysis available
maturity.level1: Rough assessment available but not documented
maturity.level2: Documented risk analysis but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Regular, documented risk analysis following a recognized standard

raQ2.title: Are your IT security measures documented in writing and regularly updated?
raQ2.tooltip: Documented security concepts are the foundation for demonstrable compliance (§30 Para. 1 BSIG). See BSI building block ISMS.1.
raQ2.help: Documented security measures mean: you have written down WHAT you do to protect your IT, e.g. 'All passwords must be at least 12 characters' or 'Backups are created daily at 10 PM.' Without written documentation, these rules are lost when an employee leaves the company.

maturity.level0: No written documentation
maturity.level1: Partially documented but outdated
maturity.level2: Largely documented but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Fully documented and updated at least annually

raQ3.title: Have you established clear responsibilities for IT security (e.g., designated contact person)?
raQ3.tooltip: NIS2 requires management accountability (§38 BSIG). Clear responsibilities are the foundation for effective security management.
raQ3.help: It must be clear WHO is responsible for IT security — even in small companies. This can be the managing director, an IT manager, or an external service provider. The key point: everyone in the company knows whom to contact for IT security questions.

maturity.level0: No defined responsibilities
maturity.level1: Informally assigned, not documented
maturity.level2: Documented but not known to all employees
maturity.level3: Clearly documented, communicated, with deputy arrangements

raQ4.title: Do you maintain a current inventory of all IT systems and digital assets (e.g., hardware, software, data)?
raQ4.tooltip: A complete asset inventory is the foundation for effective risk analysis. Without an overview of all assets, risks cannot be identified. See BSI Standard 200-2.
raQ4.help: An IT inventory is a complete list of all computers, servers, software, and databases in your company. Without this list, you cannot know whether all devices have current updates or whether outdated, insecure software is running somewhere. A simple spreadsheet with device name, location, software version, and responsible person is sufficient.

maturity.level0: No IT asset inventory exists
maturity.level1: Partial overview, but incomplete and outdated
maturity.level2: Documented inventory of key systems, but not complete
maturity.level3: Complete, current asset inventory with classification and assigned responsibilities

raQ5.title: Do you have documented risk treatment measures for identified risks (avoid, reduce, transfer, accept)?
raQ5.tooltip: Risk treatment plans document how each identified risk is handled. This is a core component of risk management per BSI Standard 200-3.
raQ5.help: For each identified risk, you should determine how to handle it: Avoid (e.g., shut down insecure software), Reduce (e.g., set up a firewall), Transfer (e.g., take out cyber insurance), or consciously Accept (e.g., for very low risks). These decisions should be documented so it's traceable why you did what.

maturity.level0: No documented risk treatment measures
maturity.level1: Informal understanding, but not documented
maturity.level2: Risk treatment plans exist for the most important risks
maturity.level3: Formal risk tolerance defined, documented treatment plans for all identified risks

ihQ1.title: Is there an established procedure for how your company responds to cyberattacks or IT disruptions?
ihQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires documented incident response processes (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. b NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 2 BSIG). See BSI building block DER.2.1.
ihQ1.help: A procedure for cyberattacks means: Who does what when it happens? For example: 'Step 1: Disconnect affected system from the network. Step 2: Call IT service provider. Step 3: Inform management.' Without such a plan, employees react with panic or not at all in an emergency.

maturity.level0: No procedure in place
maturity.level1: Ad-hoc response without fixed procedure
maturity.level2: Basic procedure documented but not regularly practiced
maturity.level3: Documented procedure with regular exercises and clear roles

ihQ2.title: Do you have emergency contact details (e.g., BSI reporting office, IT service providers) readily available?
ihQ2.tooltip: NIS2 prescribes reporting obligations (§32 BSIG). Quick response requires prepared contact lists and reporting channels.
ihQ2.help: In an emergency, every minute counts. If your email server gets hacked, you need to immediately know whom to call — your IT service provider, your internet provider, and the BSI (Federal Office for Information Security). These numbers should be printed out and readily available, not just stored digitally.

maturity.level0: No emergency contacts prepared
maturity.level1: Some contacts known but not centrally available
maturity.level2: Contact list exists but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Current contact list centrally available, including BSI reporting channels

ihQ3.title: Are security incidents logged and evaluated to learn from them?
ihQ3.tooltip: Learning from incidents is essential for improving security. See BSI building blocks DER.2.1 and OPS.1.1.5 (Logging).
ihQ3.help: Logging means: writing down what happened, when it happened, what the cause was, and what you did about it. Only this way can you recognize patterns — e.g., if the same phishing email keeps getting through — and take targeted countermeasures.

maturity.level0: No incident logging
maturity.level1: Incidents partially recorded but not systematically evaluated
maturity.level2: Systematic recording but no regular evaluation
maturity.level3: Complete recording, regular evaluation, and documented improvements

ihQ4.title: Do you have clear criteria for when an IT incident qualifies as a 'significant security incident' requiring reporting?
ihQ4.tooltip: Under Section 32 BSIG, significant security incidents must be reported to BSI within 24 hours. Clear criteria enable quick decisions in an emergency.
ihQ4.help: Under NIS2, certain incidents must be reported to the BSI within 24 hours. Reportable incidents include, e.g., a ransomware attack that paralyzes your systems or a data breach involving customer data. You need clear criteria so there's no debating in an emergency whether to report.

maturity.level0: No criteria for classifying incidents
maturity.level1: Rough understanding, but no documented criteria
maturity.level2: Basic classification exists, but not aligned with NIS2 reporting obligations
maturity.level3: Documented classification with clear thresholds and escalation levels per Section 32 BSIG

ihQ5.title: Are evidence and artifacts systematically preserved during IT security incidents (e.g., log files, network captures)?
ihQ5.tooltip: Forensic evidence preservation is essential for incident analysis and potential legal proceedings. See BSI building block DER.2.2 (IT Forensics Preparation).
ihQ5.help: Evidence preservation means securing digital traces during an incident before they are lost — e.g., log files (automatic records of who did what on the system and when), emails, or screenshots. This evidence can be important for investigation, insurance claims, or filing criminal charges.

maturity.level0: No evidence preservation during incidents
maturity.level1: Occasional manual preservation for severe incidents
maturity.level2: Basic log preservation exists, but not systematic
maturity.level3: Automated log preservation with forensic readiness and defined retention periods

bcQ1.title: Do you regularly create backups of your important data and test them?
bcQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires backup management and recovery capability (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. c NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 3 BSIG). See BSI building block CON.3.
bcQ1.help: Backups are copies of your important data — customer data, accounting, emails, contracts. What matters is not only THAT you make backups, but whether you have tested them: Can you actually restore the data? Many companies only discover during an emergency that their backup was faulty.

maturity.level0: No regular backups
maturity.level1: Backups created but not tested
maturity.level2: Regular backups with occasional recovery tests
maturity.level3: Automated backups with regularly tested recovery

bcQ2.title: Can you resume operations within 24-48 hours after a severe IT outage?
bcQ2.tooltip: Recovery capability is a core NIS2 objective. BSI Standard 200-4 describes Business Continuity Management (BCM).
bcQ2.help: Imagine your entire IT fails — no email, no ERP, no accounting. How long can you work like that? 24-48 hours is the timeframe NIS2 uses as guidance for recovery capability. For this, you need a plan of who restores what in which order.

maturity.level0: No recovery planning in place
maturity.level1: General idea but no documented plan
maturity.level2: Recovery plan exists but not tested
maturity.level3: Documented and regularly tested recovery plan

bcQ3.title: Do you have a written emergency plan for cyberattacks or system failures?
bcQ3.tooltip: Crisis management requires prepared emergency plans (§30 Para. 2 No. 3 BSIG). See BSI building block DER.4 (Emergency Management).
bcQ3.help: An emergency plan describes step by step what to do during an IT outage or cyberattack: Who gets informed? Which systems are restored first? How do you communicate with customers? This plan should be available in print — because when IT is down, you can't access it digitally.

maturity.level0: No emergency plan available
maturity.level1: Informal knowledge with individual persons
maturity.level2: Written plan available but not known to all
maturity.level3: Documented plan, known to all and regularly practiced

bcQ4.title: Have you conducted a Business Impact Analysis (BIA) identifying critical business processes and their maximum tolerable downtime?
bcQ4.tooltip: A BIA identifies critical business processes and their IT dependencies. It defines RTO (maximum downtime) and RPO (acceptable data loss). See BSI Standard 200-4.
bcQ4.help: A Business Impact Analysis (BIA) answers the question: Which business processes are so important that an outage would existentially threaten your company? For a logistics company, this might be route planning; for an online shop, the webshop. For each critical process, you define how long it may be down at most.

maturity.level0: No Business Impact Analysis conducted
maturity.level1: Informal knowledge of critical processes, but not documented
maturity.level2: Key processes identified, but without formal downtime assessment
maturity.level3: Documented BIA with RTO/RPO values for all critical business processes

bcQ5.title: Do you have a crisis communication plan for severe IT security incidents?
bcQ5.tooltip: Crisis communication governs who is informed internally and externally (employees, customers, authorities, media). Under Section 35 BSIG, service recipients may also need to be notified.
bcQ5.help: A crisis communication plan regulates who informs whom in an emergency: employees, customers, suppliers, authorities, and potentially media. Without a plan, rumors and loss of trust arise. The plan should contain text templates, contact persons, and communication channels.

maturity.level0: No crisis communication plan exists
maturity.level1: Informal agreements about who informs whom
maturity.level2: Basic plan exists, but not all stakeholders covered
maturity.level3: Documented plan with templates, communication channels, and contacts for all stakeholders

scQ1.title: Do you assess the IT security of your most important suppliers and service providers?
scQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires assessment of direct suppliers' and service providers' security (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. d NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 4 BSIG). Particularly important for cloud services and IT outsourcing.
scQ1.help: Your IT security is only as strong as the weakest link in the chain. If your cloud provider gets hacked, your data is affected. Therefore, ask your key IT service providers: Do you have a security concept? Is our data encrypted? Are there regular security audits?

maturity.level0: No assessment of supplier security
maturity.level1: Occasional informal inquiry
maturity.level2: Key suppliers assessed but not systematically
maturity.level3: Systematic assessment of all critical suppliers with documented results

scQ2.title: Do you have contractual IT security agreements with your IT service providers?
scQ2.tooltip: Contractual security requirements for service providers are an essential part of NIS2 supply chain security.
scQ2.help: Contractual security agreements mean: Your contracts with IT service providers state, e.g., that data must be encrypted, that security updates must be applied promptly, and that you must be notified in case of an incident. Without such clauses, you have no leverage in an emergency.

maturity.level0: No contractual security agreements
maturity.level1: General terms, no specific security clauses
maturity.level2: Security clauses with key service providers
maturity.level3: Standardized security requirements in all IT service provider contracts

scQ3.title: Do you know which external service providers have access to your critical systems or data?
scQ3.tooltip: Transparency about external access is a prerequisite for effective supply chain security. See BSI building block ORP.1.
scQ3.help: Many companies don't know exactly which external service providers can access their systems — e.g., the IT support, the printer maintenance service, or the accounting software provider. Create a list of all external access and check whether these are still necessary and secure.

maturity.level0: No overview of external access
maturity.level1: Partial overview, not documented
maturity.level2: Documented overview but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Complete, current overview with regular review

scQ4.title: Do you consider your suppliers' subcontractors and dependencies when assessing their security?
scQ4.tooltip: NIS2 requires consideration of the entire supply chain, not just direct suppliers. Vulnerabilities at subcontractors can compromise your organization.
scQ4.help: Your IT service provider may itself use subcontractors — e.g., a data center in another country. If a security problem occurs there, your data is also affected. Ask your service providers whether and which subcontractors they use.

maturity.level0: No consideration of subcontractors
maturity.level1: Awareness exists, but no systematic review
maturity.level2: Key suppliers are asked about their subcontractors
maturity.level3: Systematic assessment of the entire supply chain including subcontractors and dependency analysis

scQ5.title: Do you have a process for regularly reassessing the IT security of your service providers?
scQ5.tooltip: Service providers' security posture can change over time. Regular reassessment ensures your requirements are continuously met.
scQ5.help: The IT security posture of your service providers can change — e.g., through staff turnover, new threats, or changed business models. Therefore, you should check at least annually whether your requirements are still being met, e.g., through a short questionnaire or a conversation.

maturity.level0: No regular reassessment of service providers
maturity.level1: Assessment only at contract renewal
maturity.level2: Annual review of key service providers
maturity.level3: Regular, documented reassessment of all critical service providers with audit rights

adQ1.title: Are security updates for your IT systems applied promptly?
adQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires vulnerability management (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. e NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 5 BSIG). Timely patching is one of the most important protective measures. See BSI building block OPS.1.1.3.
adQ1.help: Security updates (also called 'patches') close known security vulnerabilities in your software. When, e.g., Microsoft releases an update for Windows, it should be installed within a few days. Every day of delay is an open window for attackers. This applies to all devices: servers, PCs, printers, routers.

maturity.level0: Updates not systematically applied
maturity.level1: Updates applied occasionally without fixed process
maturity.level2: Regular updates on schedule but not comprehensive
maturity.level3: Systematic patch management with prioritization and tracking

adQ2.title: Do you consider IT security aspects when purchasing or developing new software?
adQ2.tooltip: NIS2 requires security-by-design (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. e NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 5 BSIG). Security must be considered from the start. See BSI building block CON.8.
adQ2.help: When you buy or commission new software, you should ask beforehand: Is it secure? Are there regular updates? Is data encrypted? Example: Before purchasing new accounting software, check whether the vendor meets security standards and how your data is protected.

maturity.level0: Security not considered in procurement/development
maturity.level1: Occasionally considered but no fixed process
maturity.level2: Security criteria for major acquisitions but not standardized
maturity.level3: Standardized security assessment for all IT acquisitions and developments

adQ3.title: Do you have a process to identify and fix vulnerabilities in your software?
adQ3.tooltip: Vulnerability management and disclosure are explicit NIS2 requirements (§30 Para. 2 No. 5 BSIG).
adQ3.help: Vulnerabilities are bugs or gaps in software that attackers can exploit. Vulnerability management means: you have a process that detects these gaps (e.g., through automated scanners) and fixes them promptly. Without this process, you may only learn about gaps when it's too late.

maturity.level0: No vulnerability management
maturity.level1: Vulnerabilities handled ad-hoc
maturity.level2: Basic process in place but not all systems covered
maturity.level3: Systematic vulnerability management with scanning and prioritization

adQ4.title: Is IT security systematically integrated into your software development or procurement processes (Security by Design)?
adQ4.tooltip: Security by Design means considering security from the start — not as an afterthought. NIS2 explicitly requires this in Art. 21(2)(e). See BSI building block CON.8.
adQ4.help: Security by Design means that IT security is considered from the beginning during procurement or development — not as an afterthought. Example: When you commission a new customer app, it should be clear from the start how customer data will be protected, rather than adding that as an extra feature later.

maturity.level0: Security is only considered after completion or purchase
maturity.level1: Occasional security considerations, but no fixed process
maturity.level2: Security requirements defined in major projects, but not standardized
maturity.level3: Security by Design as an integral part of all development and procurement processes

adQ5.title: Do you have an overview of systems whose vendor support or security updates have expired (End-of-Life)?
adQ5.tooltip: End-of-Life systems no longer receive security updates and pose a significant risk. Lifecycle management is part of vulnerability management per Section 30(2)(5) BSIG.
adQ5.help: End-of-Life (EOL) means: the manufacturer no longer provides security updates. A typical example is Windows 10, which reached EOL in October 2025. Systems without updates are an open gateway for attackers. You should know which of your systems are affected and have a plan for migration.

maturity.level0: No overview of End-of-Life systems
maturity.level1: Rough knowledge, but no systematic tracking
maturity.level2: Overview of key systems available, but not complete
maturity.level3: Complete inventory with lifecycle status, migration timelines, and compensating controls

eaQ1.title: Do you regularly verify whether your security measures actually work (e.g., through audits)?
eaQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires regular effectiveness assessment (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. f NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 6 BSIG). See BSI building block ISMS.1.
eaQ1.help: Security measures must be regularly checked to see if they actually work. An antivirus scanner that hasn't been updated for months no longer protects. An audit (systematic review) can be conducted internally by an IT manager or externally by a service provider.

maturity.level0: No effectiveness verification
maturity.level1: Occasional informal review
maturity.level3: Systematic audits of all security measures with documented results

eaQ2.title: Do you conduct security tests (e.g., penetration tests or vulnerability scans)?
eaQ2.tooltip: Technical tests are an important part of effectiveness assessment. They reveal vulnerabilities not visible in theory.
eaQ2.help: A penetration test (pentest for short) simulates a real attack on your IT to find vulnerabilities before criminals do. A vulnerability scan automatically checks for known security gaps. For SMEs, affordable options are available starting at a few thousand euros per year.

maturity.level0: No security tests
maturity.level1: Occasional tests when specific need arises
maturity.level2: Regular vulnerability scans but no penetration tests
maturity.level3: Regular penetration tests and vulnerability scans with follow-up

eaQ3.title: Are concrete improvement actions derived and implemented from security reviews?
eaQ3.tooltip: The PDCA cycle (Plan-Do-Check-Act) is at the core of continuous improvement. See BSI building block ORP.5 (Compliance Management).
eaQ3.help: It's not enough to find security gaps — they must also be closed. If an audit shows, e.g., that passwords are too weak, a concrete measure should follow (e.g., introducing a password policy) with a responsible person and a deadline.

maturity.level0: No improvement actions derived
maturity.level1: Improvements identified but not systematically implemented
maturity.level3: Systematic improvement process with tracking and effectiveness control

eaQ4.title: Are the results of security reviews regularly reported to management?
eaQ4.tooltip: Under Section 38 BSIG, management must oversee the implementation of risk management measures. Regular reporting is a prerequisite for this.
eaQ4.help: Management is personally responsible for IT security under NIS2 (§38 BSIG). Therefore, they must regularly learn about the security status. A simple report, e.g., quarterly, with the current status and the biggest risks is sufficient.

maturity.level0: No reporting to management
maturity.level1: Only for serious incidents
maturity.level2: Occasional reports, but no fixed schedule
maturity.level3: Regular, structured reporting to management with actionable recommendations

eaQ5.title: Do you use measurable key performance indicators (KPIs) to assess your IT security posture?
eaQ5.tooltip: Security KPIs such as patch rate, training completion, or mean response time make security status measurable and improvements demonstrable.
eaQ5.help: KPIs (Key Performance Indicators) are metrics that make your security status measurable. Examples: What percentage of devices have current updates? How quickly do you respond to security incidents? How many employees have completed security training? Without such figures, you cannot demonstrate progress.

maturity.level0: No security KPIs defined
maturity.level1: Individual ad-hoc figures (e.g., number of incidents)
maturity.level2: Basic KPIs defined, but not regularly collected
maturity.level3: Comprehensive KPI set (e.g., MTTD, MTTR, patch rate, training rate) with regular evaluation

chQ1.title: Are your employees regularly trained on IT security topics (e.g., recognizing phishing)?
chQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires basic training (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. g NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 7 BSIG). See BSI building block ORP.3.
chQ1.help: Most successful cyberattacks exploit human errors — e.g., an employee clicks a link in a forged email (phishing). Regular training (at least annually) helps recognize such attacks. This can be a one-hour online course, not an elaborate seminar.

maturity.level0: No IT security training
maturity.level1: One-time or occasional advice
maturity.level2: Annual training but not reaching all employees
maturity.level3: Regular training for all employees with effectiveness verification

chQ2.title: Are there clear guidelines for secure behavior (e.g., password rules, handling emails)?
chQ2.tooltip: Cyber hygiene guidelines define minimum standards for secure work. They form the basis for training and awareness.
chQ2.help: Security guidelines are simple, clear rules for all employees, e.g.: 'Passwords must be at least 12 characters long and must not be shared,' 'Unknown USB sticks are not to be connected,' 'Report suspicious emails to IT immediately.' These rules should be in writing and known to everyone.

maturity.level0: No guidelines available
maturity.level1: Informal rules, not written down
maturity.level2: Written guidelines available but not known to all
maturity.level3: Current guidelines known to all employees and regularly reviewed

chQ3.title: Are new employees systematically introduced to IT security topics?
chQ3.tooltip: Security onboarding ensures new employees act security-consciously from the start. See BSI building block ORP.2.
chQ3.help: New employees are particularly vulnerable because they don't yet know the internal security rules. A systematic briefing on the first day of work — e.g., 'How to recognize phishing emails' and 'Whom to contact for IT problems' — significantly reduces this risk.

maturity.level0: No security introduction at onboarding
maturity.level1: Occasional verbal advice
maturity.level3: Documented security introduction as a fixed part of onboarding

chQ4.title: Do you conduct simulated phishing tests to assess employee vigilance?
chQ4.tooltip: Phishing simulations are an effective tool for measuring and improving security awareness. They identify specific training needs.
chQ4.help: In a phishing simulation, your employees receive a controlled test email that looks like a real attack. This shows you who falls for it, and you can provide targeted follow-up training. This is one of the most effective awareness measures and is offered as a service by many IT providers.

maturity.level0: No phishing simulations
maturity.level1: Tested once or occasionally
maturity.level2: Regular simulations, but without individual follow-up training
maturity.level3: Regular phishing simulations with targeted follow-up training for failures and trend analysis

chQ5.title: Are your management and executives regularly trained on NIS2 obligations and cybersecurity?
chQ5.tooltip: Section 38 BSIG personally obligates management to oversee risk management measures and participate in regular training. This duty cannot be delegated.
chQ5.help: Under §38 BSIG, managing directors must personally participate in cybersecurity training — this obligation cannot be delegated. The training must cover NIS2 obligations, personal liability of management, and basic cybersecurity topics. This also helps leadership make informed decisions about security investments.

maturity.level0: No specific training for management
maturity.level1: One-time information about NIS2 requirements
maturity.level2: Occasional briefings, but no fixed training program
maturity.level3: Regular, documented management training per Section 38 BSIG with attendance records

crQ1.title: Are confidential data encrypted during storage and transmission (e.g., via HTTPS, VPN)?
crQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires the use of cryptographic measures (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. h NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 8 BSIG). See BSI building block CON.1.
crQ1.help: Encryption makes data unreadable to unauthorized persons. HTTPS (the lock symbol in the browser) encrypts data during internet transmission. VPN encrypts the connection to your company network. Stored data (e.g., on laptops) should also be encrypted so it cannot be read if stolen.

maturity.level0: No encryption in use
maturity.level1: Partial encryption (e.g., HTTPS for website only)
maturity.level2: Encryption for most sensitive data but gaps exist
maturity.level3: Comprehensive encryption of all sensitive data at rest and in transit

crQ2.title: Do you have a concept for which data must be encrypted and with which methods?
crQ2.tooltip: A cryptography concept defines where encryption is used and which algorithms/key lengths are applied. See BSI building block CON.1.
crQ2.help: A crypto concept defines: Which data must be encrypted (e.g., customer data, personnel files) and with which method? Not all data needs the same level of protection. A price list needs less protection than banking details. This concept helps set the right priorities.

maturity.level0: No cryptography concept available
maturity.level1: Encryption used ad-hoc without concept
maturity.level2: Basic concept available but not fully implemented
maturity.level3: Documented cryptography concept with current methods and regular review

crQ3.title: Are cryptographic keys managed securely (e.g., not stored in plain text)?
crQ3.tooltip: Key management is critical: compromised keys render encryption worthless. Secure storage and regular rotation are essential.
crQ3.help: Cryptographic keys are like digital passwords for encryption. If a key is stolen, the encryption is worthless. Keys should therefore never be stored in plain text in files, but in secured systems — and should be changed regularly.

maturity.level0: No conscious key management
maturity.level1: Keys stored without special protection
maturity.level2: Basic protection measures but no systematic management
maturity.level3: Systematic key management with secure storage and rotation

crQ4.title: Are your SSL/TLS certificates and cryptographic keys centrally managed and monitored?
crQ4.tooltip: Expired or compromised certificates can cause outages and security vulnerabilities. Central monitoring prevents unnoticed expiration dates.
crQ4.help: SSL/TLS certificates secure, e.g., your website (HTTPS) or email server. If a certificate expires unnoticed, your website suddenly stops working or shows security warnings. A central overview with expiration dates prevents such outages.

maturity.level0: No central certificate management
maturity.level1: Certificates managed manually, no expiration monitoring
maturity.level2: Overview of key certificates exists, but no automated monitoring
maturity.level3: Central certificate management with automated expiration monitoring and renewal process

crQ5.title: Are you prepared for a potential change in cryptographic methods (crypto agility)?
crQ5.tooltip: Crypto agility describes the ability to quickly switch to new cryptographic methods — e.g., when current algorithms are classified as insecure or post-quantum cryptography becomes necessary.
crQ5.help: Crypto agility means: Can you quickly switch to new encryption methods if current ones are classified as insecure? With the development of quantum computers, today's methods could potentially be broken in the future. You should at least know which methods you currently use.

maturity.level0: No preparation for crypto migration
maturity.level1: Awareness exists, but no concrete measures
maturity.level2: Inventory of used methods created, but no migration plan
maturity.level3: Crypto agility assessed, migration plan for outdated methods created, BSI recommendations monitored

acQ1.title: Do only authorized persons have access to critical IT systems and data?
acQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires access control following the principle of least privilege (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. i NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 9 BSIG). See BSI building block ORP.4.
acQ1.help: Access control means: Each employee can only access the data and systems they need for their work. The apprentice in accounting doesn't need access to personnel files. The principle is called 'Least Privilege' (minimum authorization) and is one of the most basic security measures.

maturity.level0: No systematic access control
maturity.level1: Basic access restrictions but no differentiated rights
maturity.level2: Role-based access rights for important systems
maturity.level3: Comprehensive access control with least-privilege principle and regular review

acQ2.title: Are access rights regularly reviewed and immediately revoked when employees leave?
acQ2.tooltip: Outdated access rights are a common security risk. Regular review prevents unauthorized access.
acQ2.help: When an employee leaves the company, ALL access must be revoked IMMEDIATELY — email, VPN, cloud services, building access. At the same time, existing rights should be regularly reviewed: Does Mr. Smith really still need access to the project that was completed two years ago?

maturity.level0: No review, old rights remain active
maturity.level1: Rights revoked on departure but no regular review
maturity.level2: Regular review but not all systems covered
maturity.level3: Systematic rights review across all systems with immediate revocation on departure

acQ3.title: Are physical access controls in place for critical IT areas (e.g., server room)?
acQ3.tooltip: Physical protection of critical IT infrastructure is part of access control. See BSI building blocks INF.1 (Building) and INF.2 (Data Center).
acQ3.help: Physical access controls protect your IT hardware from unauthorized access. The minimum: The server room is locked and only authorized persons have a key. Better: Electronic access control with logging of who entered the room and when.

maturity.level0: No special physical protection
maturity.level1: Server room locked but no access log
maturity.level2: Access control with key/card but no logging
maturity.level3: Electronic access control with logging and regular review

acQ4.title: Are privileged accounts (admin accounts) specially protected and monitored?
acQ4.tooltip: Privileged accounts are the most common target for attackers. Special protection through MFA, logging, and regular review is essential. See BSI building block ORP.4.
acQ4.help: Admin accounts (administrator accounts) have the highest permissions and are therefore the primary target of attackers. They should be specially protected: separate strong password, multi-factor authentication, and used only for administrative tasks — not for everyday work like reading emails.

maturity.level0: No special protection for privileged accounts
maturity.level1: Individual measures (e.g., separate admin password), but not systematic
maturity.level2: Privileged accounts identified and secured with additional measures
maturity.level3: Complete Privileged Access Management with MFA, activity logging, and regular review

acQ5.title: Are access rights regularly recertified (i.e., systematically checked whether existing rights are still needed)?
acQ5.tooltip: Recertification ensures access rights follow the least-privilege principle. Without regular review, unnecessary rights accumulate (Privilege Creep).
acQ5.help: Recertification means: At regular intervals (e.g., annually), it is systematically checked whether each employee still needs the access rights they have. Over time, unnecessary rights often accumulate (e.g., through department changes). This 'privilege creep' is a common security risk.

maturity.level0: No recertification of access rights
maturity.level1: Rights are only checked when issues arise
maturity.level3: Regular recertification of all access rights with documented approval process

mcQ1.title: Do you use multi-factor authentication (e.g., authenticator app, hardware token) for critical systems?
mcQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires MFA for privileged access (Art. 21 Abs. 2 lit. j NIS2-RL, §30 Para. 2 No. 10 BSIG). MFA protects against password theft and unauthorized access.
mcQ1.help: Multi-factor authentication (MFA) means: To log in, you need not only a password but also a second factor — e.g., a code from an app on your smartphone. Even if someone steals your password, they cannot log in without the second factor. MFA blocks over 99% of all account takeovers.

maturity.level0: No MFA in use
maturity.level1: MFA for individual systems (e.g., cloud email only)
maturity.level3: MFA for all critical systems and privileged access

mcQ2.title: Is confidential communication encrypted (e.g., encrypted emails, secure video conferences)?
mcQ2.tooltip: Secured communication protects against eavesdropping and manipulation. NIS2 requires secured voice, video and text communication (§30 Para. 2 No. 10 BSIG).
mcQ2.help: Encrypted communication means that emails and video conferences cannot be read by third parties. For emails, there is e.g. S/MIME or TLS transport encryption. For video conferences, services like Microsoft Teams or Zoom offer end-to-end encryption.

maturity.level0: No encrypted communication
maturity.level1: Partially encrypted (e.g., internal chats only)
maturity.level2: Encrypted communication for most sensitive topics
maturity.level3: Comprehensive encrypted communication for all confidential content

mcQ3.title: Do you have secure communication channels for emergencies (e.g., alternative channels during IT outage)?
mcQ3.tooltip: Secured emergency communication ensures your crisis team remains reachable even during IT outages (§30 Para. 2 No. 10 BSIG).
mcQ3.help: If your entire IT fails, email and Teams won't work either. For this case, you need an emergency channel — e.g., a phone list on paper, a messenger group on personal phones, or a separate service. This channel must be established and tested beforehand.

maturity.level0: No emergency communication prepared
maturity.level1: Personal phone numbers as informal emergency channel
maturity.level2: Defined emergency channel but not tested
maturity.level3: Tested emergency communication with secure, independent channels

mcQ4.title: Do you use context-based access policies (e.g., depending on location, device, or time)?
mcQ4.tooltip: Conditional Access allows differentiated access rules based on the login context — e.g., stricter requirements for external access or unknown devices.
mcQ4.help: Context-based access policies adapt security requirements to the situation. Example: An employee logging in from the office PC only needs their password. The same employee logging in from abroad via unfamiliar Wi-Fi must additionally use MFA. This way, security is specifically increased where the risk is higher.

maturity.level0: No context-based access rules
maturity.level1: Basic restrictions (e.g., VPN required from external)
maturity.level2: Context-based rules for critical systems (e.g., IP restriction, device check)
maturity.level3: Comprehensive conditional access policies with risk assessment per context

mcQ5.title: Is communication between your locations and field workers consistently encrypted?
mcQ5.tooltip: Cross-location communication over public networks must be encrypted. Site-to-site VPN and always-on VPN for mobile devices are proven measures.
mcQ5.help: When your employees communicate between locations or from home offices, data travels over the public internet. Without a VPN (Virtual Private Network), this data could theoretically be intercepted. A VPN connection encrypts all data traffic — like a private tunnel through the internet.

maturity.level0: No cross-location encryption
maturity.level1: VPN available, but not consistently used
maturity.level2: VPN required for remote access, but not all connections secured
maturity.level3: Consistent encryption of all cross-location connections including always-on VPN

ra1.title: Create an IT Risk Inventory
ra1.description: Systematically identify all critical IT systems, data, and processes along with their threats.
ra1.firstStep: List your 5 most important IT systems and assess their criticality for business operations.

ra2.title: Define Security Responsibilities
ra2.description: Appoint an IT security officer and document responsibilities and reporting lines.
ra2.firstStep: Designate a responsible person for IT security and communicate this to all employees.

ih1.title: Create an Incident Response Plan
ih1.description: Create a documented plan for responding to security incidents with clear roles and procedures.
ih1.firstStep: Define the 3 most common incident scenarios (e.g., ransomware, phishing, data loss) and describe initial response steps.

ih2.title: Compile Emergency Contacts
ih2.description: Create a current contact list with internal contacts, external IT service providers, and BSI reporting channels.
ih2.firstStep: Collect your IT service provider's contact details and learn about the BSI reporting obligation (meldestelle@bsi.bund.de).

bc1.title: Implement a Backup Strategy
bc1.description: Implement a 3-2-1 backup strategy: 3 copies, 2 media types, 1 offsite. Regularly test recovery.
bc1.firstStep: Check if automatic backups are set up for your most important data and test a recovery.

bc2.title: Create an Emergency Plan
bc2.description: Create an IT emergency plan with recovery priorities, responsibilities, and communication channels.
bc2.firstStep: Identify your 5 most important business processes and define their maximum tolerable downtime.

sc1.title: Create a Supplier Overview
sc1.description: Document all external IT service providers and their access to your systems and data.
sc1.firstStep: Create a list of all external service providers that have access to your IT systems or data.

sc2.title: Add Security Clauses to Contracts
sc2.description: Add security requirements and audit rights to IT service provider contracts.
sc2.firstStep: Review your most important IT service provider contract for existing security clauses.

ad1.title: Implement Patch Management
ad1.description: Establish a process for timely application of security updates across all systems.
ad1.firstStep: Enable automatic OS updates and create a list of all software in use.

ad2.title: Security Assessment for Acquisitions
ad2.description: Integrate security criteria into the procurement process for new IT systems and software.
ad2.firstStep: Create a checklist with security criteria (encryption, update frequency, vendor support) for IT procurements.

ea1.title: Introduce Regular Security Reviews
ea1.description: Plan at least annual reviews of your security measures, internally or through external auditors.
ea1.firstStep: Schedule a first review of your most important security measures within the next 3 months.

ea2.title: Conduct Vulnerability Scans
ea2.description: Perform regular technical security tests to identify vulnerabilities early.
ea2.firstStep: Research free vulnerability scanners (e.g., OpenVAS) or commission an external penetration test.

ch1.title: Start an Awareness Training Program
ch1.description: Introduce regular IT security training for all employees, at least annually.
ch1.firstStep: Organize a first training session on phishing recognition for all employees.

ch2.title: Document Security Guidelines
ch2.description: Create understandable guidelines for passwords, email security, mobile devices, and remote work.
ch2.firstStep: Write a one-page password policy (minimum length, complexity, no reuse).

cr1.title: Implement Encryption Standards
cr1.description: Ensure all sensitive data is encrypted during storage and transmission.
cr1.firstStep: Check if your website uses HTTPS and if emails with sensitive content are sent encrypted.

cr2.title: Create a Cryptography Concept
cr2.description: Document where encryption is used, which methods and key lengths you employ.
cr2.firstStep: Create an overview of all places where encryption is or should be used.

ac1.title: Implement Role-Based Access Control
ac1.description: Implement the principle of least privilege: every employee receives only the rights needed for their role.
ac1.firstStep: Review admin rights: which employees have administrator access and do they really need it?

ac2.title: Offboarding Process for IT Access
ac2.description: Ensure all IT access is immediately deactivated when employees leave.
ac2.firstStep: Create a checklist of all systems and access that must be deactivated when an employee departs.

mc1.title: Activate MFA for Critical Systems
mc1.description: Enable multi-factor authentication for all critical systems, starting with email and VPN.
mc1.firstStep: Enable MFA for your business email (Microsoft 365, Google Workspace) and document the setup.

mc2.title: Set Up Secure Communication Channels
mc2.description: Provide encrypted communication channels for confidential business content and emergencies.
mc2.firstStep: Set up an encrypted messenger (e.g., Signal) as emergency communication channel and share contacts with the crisis team.

ra3.title: Create IT Asset Register and Risk Treatment Plan
ra3.description: Create a complete inventory of all IT assets and define a treatment plan for each identified risk (avoid, reduce, transfer, accept).
ra3.firstStep: Create a spreadsheet with columns: Asset Name, Type, Location, Owner, Criticality (high/medium/low), and Last Review Date.
checklist: Create IT asset inventory (hardware, software, data, network)

ih3.title: Establish NIS2-Compliant Reporting Process per Section 32 BSIG
ih3.description: Establish a documented reporting process for significant security incidents with the three legal reporting stages: initial notification (24h), follow-up (72h), and final report (1 month).
ih3.firstStep: Create a reporting obligation flowchart: Incident detected → Significant? → 24h initial report to BSI → 72h update → Final report within one month.
checklist: Document BSI contact details and reporting channels

bc3.title: Conduct Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
bc3.description: Conduct a structured BIA to identify critical business processes and determine their maximum tolerable downtime (RTO) and acceptable data loss (RPO).
bc3.firstStep: Identify your 10 most important business processes and assess the impact of a 1-hour, 1-day, and 1-week outage for each.
checklist: Define minimum resources for emergency operations

sc3.title: Systematize Supplier Security Assessment
sc3.description: Implement a standardized process for assessing IT security of your suppliers, including regular review and contractual security requirements.
sc3.firstStep: Create a supplier security questionnaire with 15-20 questions covering access control, encryption, incident management, and certifications.
checklist: Create supplier directory with criticality levels
Agree on audit rights in contracts
Plan annual reassessment of critical suppliers

ad3.title: Introduce Structured Patch Management Process
ad3.description: Implement a patch management process with defined timeframes: Critical patches within 24-48h, high priority within 7 days, medium within 30 days.
ad3.firstStep: Create a complete list of all software and operating systems in use with their current patch levels.
checklist: Create software inventory with version numbers
Document exception process for non-patchable systems
Regularly verify and report patch compliance

ea3.title: Introduce Security KPIs and Management Reporting
ea3.description: Define measurable security metrics and report them regularly to management. This simultaneously fulfills management obligations under Section 38 BSIG.
ea3.firstStep: Start with 5 basic KPIs: open vulnerabilities, patch compliance rate, training completion rate, backup success rate, security incidents per month.
checklist: Identify data sources and collection methods

ch3.title: Establish Management Training Program per Section 38 BSIG
ch3.description: Set up a regular training program for management. Under Section 38 BSIG, managers are personally obligated to approve risk management measures and oversee their implementation.
ch3.firstStep: Organize an initial NIS2 briefing for management: applicability, personal liability (Section 38 BSIG), penalty risk, and next steps.
checklist: Conduct NIS2 overview briefing for management
Explain personal liability risks under Section 38 BSIG
Create annual training plan for management
Define approval obligations for risk management

cr3.title: Introduce Certificate and Key Management
cr3.description: Implement centralized management for SSL/TLS certificates and cryptographic keys with automated expiration monitoring and documented renewal processes.
cr3.firstStep: Create an overview of all SSL/TLS certificates with expiration date, issuer, and responsible person.
checklist: Assess crypto agility for algorithm changes

ac3.title: Introduce Privileged Access Management (PAM)
ac3.description: Implement special protection for privileged accounts (admin accounts): MFA, activity logging, and regular recertification.
ac3.firstStep: Create a complete list of all admin accounts and verify whether each is still needed and whether MFA is enabled.
checklist: Enable MFA for all admin accounts
Set up activity logging for admin access

mc3.title: Implement Secure Site Connectivity and Mobile Access
mc3.description: Ensure all cross-location connections and employee remote access are consistently encrypted.
mc3.firstStep: Verify that VPN connections are enforced for all external access and that site-to-site connections are encrypted.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions About Your Results

q1.question: What do the traffic light colors (red/yellow/green) mean?
q1.answer: Red indicates significant action required (below 40%), yellow indicates improvement needed (40–69%), and green signals good implementation (70% and above). The thresholds are based on common maturity models.

q2.question: Am I automatically NIS2-compliant with a green score?
q2.answer: No. A high score indicates that your self-assessment suggests good implementation. However, NIS2 compliance requires professional evaluation of the adequacy and effectiveness of your measures (§30 para. 1 BSIG).

q3.question: Can I forward the PDF report to my IT service provider?
q3.answer: Yes, the PDF report is designed exactly for that purpose. It contains all scores, recommendations, and the roadmap — ideal as a discussion basis for IT service providers, consultants, or management.

q4.question: How can I improve my score?
q4.answer: Start with the Quick Wins and the red-flagged categories. Each recommendation includes a concrete first step. The 3-phase roadmap gives you a prioritized implementation plan.

q5.question: Are my results still saved when I close the browser?
q5.answer: Yes. Your answers and results are saved in your browser's localStorage and are available on your next visit — until you clear your browser data or reset the analysis.

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.intro: You can read this report without IT expertise. The key technical terms are explained here in everyday language.

isms.def: Information Security Management System — a systematic approach to plan, implement, and continuously improve information security in your organization.

bia.def: Business Impact Analysis — identifies which business processes are most affected by IT outages and how quickly they need to be restored.

rto.def: Recovery Time Objective — the maximum acceptable time until a system is functional again after an outage. Example: RTO 4h = email must be back within 4 hours.

rpo.def: Recovery Point Objective — how much data loss is acceptable. Example: RPO 1h = backups at least hourly, so maximum 1 hour of work is lost.

bcm.def: Business Continuity Management — planning and measures to keep your organization running during IT outages, natural disasters, or cyberattacks.

mfa.def: Multi-Factor Authentication — login using two or more factors (e.g. password + SMS code). Protects accounts even if a password is stolen.

pam.def: Privileged Access Management — special security for admin accounts and critical access points that could cause the most damage if misused.

siem.def: Security Information and Event Management — software that centrally collects security events from all IT systems and alerts on anomalies.

soc.def: Security Operations Center — a team (internal or external) that monitors IT security around the clock and responds to incidents.

ioc.def: Indicator of Compromise — technical clues (e.g. suspicious IP addresses, file hashes) that suggest a system has been compromised.

patchMgmt.def: The systematic process of promptly applying security updates across all systems — one of the most effective protective measures overall.

zeroTrust.def: Security approach where no user or device is automatically trusted — every access is individually verified, even within the corporate network.

riskTreatment.def: A document that specifies for each identified risk whether to avoid, mitigate, transfer, or accept it — and who is responsible by when.

audit.def: A systematic review of whether your IT security measures meet requirements (e.g. NIS2, ISO 27001). Can be performed internally or by external auditors.

compliance.def: Adherence to legal regulations and regulatory requirements — in the NIS2 context: demonstrable implementation of IT security measures per Section 30 BSIG.

meldepflichten.title: Reporting Obligations under §32 BSIG
meldepflichten.subtitle: Three-stage reporting process for significant security incidents
meldepflichten.intro: The NIS2 Implementation Act requires affected entities to report significant security incidents to the BSI without undue delay. The reporting process comprises three stages with fixed deadlines.

stage1.title: Initial Notification (24 hours)
stage1.description: Immediate initial notification to the BSI with basic information about the incident.
stage1.content: Initial assessment: nature and severity of the incident, suspected cross-border impact, initial suspicions regarding the cause.

stage2.title: Follow-up Report (72 hours)
stage2.description: Update of the initial notification with more detailed information.
stage2.content: Updated assessment: severity and impact, indicators of compromise (IoCs), countermeasures taken and planned.

stage3.title: Final Report (1 month)
stage3.deadline: No later than one month after the initial notification
stage3.description: Comprehensive final report on the incident and measures taken.
stage3.content: Detailed description: root cause analysis, type of threat, remedial measures taken, cross-border impact, lessons learned.

criteria.title: When is a Security Incident Considered Significant?
criteria.subtitle: A security incident is considered significant under §32 para. 4 BSIG if at least one of the following criteria is met:

items.disruption: Severe operational disruption of services or financial losses for the entity
items.damage: Considerable material or immaterial damage to other natural or legal persons

dsgvoComparison.title: Comparison: NIS2 vs. GDPR Reporting Obligations
dsgvoComparison.parallel: Note: If an incident falls under both NIS2 and GDPR, both reporting channels must be used in parallel.

meldepflichten.legalBasis: Legal basis: §32 BSIG in conjunction with Art. 23 NIS2 Directive

geschaeftsleitung.title: Management Accountability under §38 BSIG
geschaeftsleitung.subtitle: Personal duties and liability risks for management
geschaeftsleitung.intro: The NIS2 Implementation Act establishes personal responsibility for management under §38 BSIG. These duties are non-delegable and encompass approval, monitoring, and training.

implement.title: Approve Risk Management Measures
implement.description: Management must approve the risk management measures required under §30 BSIG.

monitor.title: Monitor Implementation
monitor.description: Management must monitor the implementation of approved measures and can be held responsible for violations.

train.title: Regular Training
train.description: Management must regularly participate in training to acquire sufficient knowledge and skills for identifying and assessing risks.

personalLiability.title: Personal Liability
personalLiability.description: Management members are liable to the entity for damages caused by breach of their duties under §38 BSIG, according to the rules applicable to the legal form.

noWaiver.title: No Waiver Possible
noWaiver.description: A waiver of the entity's claims for damages against management is void. Settlements are only permitted if the entity is insolvent.

training.title: Training Obligation
training.description: Management must regularly participate in training. This cannot be fully delegated to third parties.

items.riskApproval: Risk management measures formally approved per §30 BSIG
items.responsibility: IT security responsibilities documented and communicated
items.budget: Adequate budget allocated for IT security

items.schedule: Annual training plan for management created

items.review: At least quarterly management reviews conducted

items.insurance: D&O insurance reviewed for NIS2 coverage

geschaeftsleitung.legalBasis: Legal basis: §38 BSIG in conjunction with Art. 20 NIS2 Directive

registrierung.title: Registration Guide under §§33-34 BSIG
registrierung.subtitle: Step-by-step guide for BSI registration
registrierung.intro: Affected entities must register with the BSI within three months of the NIS2 Implementation Act taking effect. Registration is done via the BSI portal.

deadline.title: Deadlines
deadline.note: The registration obligation applies from the time the entity first falls under the regulations.

step1.title: 1. Check Affected Status
step1.description: Use the affected check to determine whether your company falls under NIS2 and which category it is assigned to.

step2.title: 2. Create Business Account
step2.description: Create a business account on the federal Mein Unternehmenskonto (MUK) portal if you haven't already.

step3.title: 3. Access BSI Portal
step3.description: Navigate to the BSI registration portal and sign in with your business account.

step4.title: 4. Enter Details
step4.description: Enter all required data about your company (see checklist below).

step5.title: 5. Submit Registration
step5.description: Review all entries and submit the registration.

step6.title: 6. Await Confirmation
step6.description: The BSI will confirm the registration. You will receive access credentials for the reporting portal.

items.address: Address of headquarters and any other EU establishments
items.sector: Sector and sub-sector per Annex 1/2 BSIG
items.responsiblePerson: Name and contact of the responsible person

registrierung.legalBasis: Legal basis: §§33-34 BSIG in conjunction with Art. 3(3), Art. 27 NIS2 Directive

bussgeld.title: Penalty Calculator
bussgeld.subtitle: Estimated maximum penalty risk under §65 BSIG
bussgeld.intro: The NIS2 Implementation Act provides for significant penalties. The amount depends on the entity's classification and annual revenue.

explanation.besondersWichtig: For essential entities, the maximum penalty is up to EUR 10,000,000 or 2% of global annual revenue — whichever is higher.
explanation.wichtig: For important entities, the maximum penalty is up to EUR 7,000,000 or 1.4% of global annual revenue — whichever is higher.

bussgeld.note: Note: The actual penalty amount is determined by the competent authority on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the severity of the violation, possible recurrence, and countermeasures taken.

dsgvoOverlap.title: GDPR Overlap Analysis
dsgvoOverlap.subtitle: Leveraging synergies between NIS2 and GDPR compliance
dsgvoOverlap.intro: Approximately 60% of NIS2 requirements overlap with existing GDPR measures. Companies with existing GDPR compliance have a head start on NIS2 implementation.

riskAssessment.gap: NIS2 requires formal risk analysis per state of the art, not just 'appropriate' measures

incidentHandling.gap: NIS2: 24h deadline (vs. 72h GDPR), BSI as reporting authority (vs. DPA)

businessContinuity.gap: NIS2 requires comprehensive BCM including crisis management, not just recovery

supplyChain.gap: NIS2 requires IT security assessment of all suppliers, not just processors

securityMeasures.gap: NIS2 requires vulnerability management and secure procurement

effectiveness.gap: NIS2 requires demonstrable effectiveness testing (audits, pentests)

training.gap: NIS2 mandates management training (§38 BSIG) — not just general awareness

encryption.gap: NIS2 requires documented crypto concept with key management

accessControl.gap: NIS2 requires MFA, PAM, and regular access recertification

documentation.gap: NIS2 requires comprehensive documentation of all security measures

iso27001.subtitle: Mapping NIS2 requirements to ISO 27001:2022 Annex A Controls
iso27001.intro: Companies with existing ISO 27001 certification have a significant head start on NIS2 implementation. Average coverage is approximately 72%.

gaps.riskAnalysis: NIS2 requires explicit inclusion of supply chain risks and regulatory requirements
gaps.incidentHandling: NIS2 has stricter reporting deadlines (24h/72h) and specific BSI reporting obligations
gaps.businessContinuity: NIS2 requires explicit crisis management and shorter recovery times
gaps.supplyChain: NIS2 goes beyond ISO: cybersecurity-specific supplier assessment mandatory
gaps.acquisitionDevelopment: NIS2 requires secure-by-design and explicit vulnerability management

water.challenges: Water suppliers often operate widely distributed infrastructures with remote control technology that needs special protection.

iris2.description: EU Secure Connectivity Programme with cybersecurity requirements for satellite infrastructure, including risk and threat analyses for ground and space segments

space.challenges: The space sector faces unique challenges: satellite systems are difficult to patch and operate over long periods. Ground infrastructures are the centre of compliance requirements. These systems often have lifecycles of 10-25 years and frequently lack modern authentication or encryption. The convergence of waste logistics, environmental monitoring, and digital control technology requires integrated security concepts.
waste.recommendations: Prioritize complete inventorying of all OT/SCADA systems and implement strict network segmentation between IT and OT networks following the Purdue model. Introduce dedicated OT risk management and develop contingency plans that enable minimum operations even in case of digital control system failure.

chemicals.challenges: Chemical plants face the challenge of ensuring cybersecurity and plant safety simultaneously. Cyberattacks on ICS/SCADA can trigger hazardous reactions, environmental damage, or major accidents. The overlap between Seveso III, IEC 62443, and NIS2 creates complex multi-regulatory compliance demands.
chemicals.recommendations: Create a complete inventory of all IT and OT assets in accordance with KAS-44 and implement strict network segmentation between corporate IT and process control technology. Use the IEC 62443 standard series as a technical framework. Integrate your major accident emergency planning with the cyber incident response plan.

foodlaw.name: EU General Food Law Regulation / LFGB
foodlaw.description: Regulation (EC) 178/2002 requires complete traceability at all stages of production and distribution. With increasing digitalisation of traceability systems, their cybersecurity gains significant importance in the NIS2 context.

food.challenges: Food companies must secure digitally connected traceability systems, cold chain IT, and HACCP documentation systems against cyberattacks. An attack on temperature monitoring systems can directly endanger food safety. A cybersecurity incident can simultaneously trigger food law and NIS2 reporting obligations.
food.recommendations: Use existing HACCP and IFS/BRC documentation structures as a foundation for NIS2 risk management ('Cyber-HACCP'). Secure cold chain monitoring systems and traceability databases through access controls and offline backups. Ensure your incident response plan addresses both NIS2 and food law reporting obligations.

dsa.name: Digital Services Act (DSA)
dsa.description: EU-wide rules for platform operators, online marketplaces, and search engines. DSA obligations regarding user safety and platform integrity overlap with NIS2 cybersecurity requirements.

tdddg.name: TDDDG (formerly TTDSG)
tdddg.description: Governs data protection and privacy in digital services in Germany, including cookie consent requirements and confidentiality. Overlaps with NIS2 in technical protective measures for user data.

digitalServices.challenges: Digital service providers are subject to a light-touch supervisory regime but must still fulfill all risk management and reporting obligations. Key challenges include DDoS protection while ensuring high availability, protecting user data across multiple regulatory frameworks (DSA, GDPR, TDDDG, NIS2), and safeguarding the integrity of content delivery systems and recommender algorithms.
digitalServices.recommendations: Implement an integrated compliance framework covering NIS2, DSA, and TDDDG requirements. Establish robust DDoS protection, automated anomaly detection, and a multi-tier incident response procedure with 24-hour reporting capability. Conduct regular security audits of platform architecture including API security.

dualuse.description: Regulation (EU) 2021/821 governs export controls for dual-use goods. Research outputs with dual-use potential are subject to special security requirements that overlap with NIS2 obligations.

gdprResearch.name: GDPR Research Privilege
gdprResearch.description: Art. 89 GDPR grants research institutions special privileges for data processing but requires appropriate technical safeguards (pseudonymisation, data minimisation) that overlap with NIS2 requirements.

research.challenges: Research institutions must protect intellectual property and confidential research data while maintaining scientific openness and collaboration capability. Dual-use research outputs are subject to special export control and security requirements. International research partnerships and data exchange platforms must be secured against industrial espionage and state-sponsored cyber attacks.
research.recommendations: Implement systematic data classification distinguishing between open, confidential, and export-controlled (dual-use) data. Establish a dedicated ISMS for research IT and contractually obligate international cooperation partners to appropriate security standards. Regularly train scientific staff on IT security and secure handling of sensitive research data.

it-sicherheitspolicy.name: IT Security Policy
it-sicherheitspolicy.scenario:
A mid-size machinery manufacturer falls victim to a ransomware attack. Investigation reveals: there was no documented IT security policy. Employees used personal USB drives, passwords were shared, and nobody knew who was responsible in an emergency. The damage: 3 weeks of production downtime, €180,000 in direct costs.

Without a binding IT security policy, there's no foundation for any further measures — and nothing to show in an audit.
it-sicherheitspolicy.solution:
1. Download template and adapt to your organization (2-3 pages suffice)
2. Define key points: scope, responsibilities, password rules, media handling, reporting channels
3. Have management sign it (legally required under NIS2)
4. Communicate to all employees (email + intranet + bulletin board)
5. Schedule annual review and update
it-sicherheitspolicy.benefit: A documented IT security policy is the foundation for every audit and certification. It significantly reduces management liability and creates clear guidelines for all employees. Insurers offer up to 10% discount on cyber policies.
it-sicherheitspolicy.nextStep: Create your IT security policy with our 2-page template. Customize it and have management sign it.

schulungskonzept.name: Training Concept
schulungskonzept.scenario:
An accountant opens a perfectly forged email from the supposed CEO and transfers €45,000 to a foreign account (CEO fraud). The reason: not a single employee had ever been trained in IT security. Phishing emails, social engineering, and secure passwords were never a topic.

92% of all cyberattacks start with the human factor. Without training, your employees are the weakest link.
schulungskonzept.solution:
1. Schedule annual basic training (2h) for all employees
2. Content: recognizing phishing, secure passwords, reporting channels, social engineering
3. Quarterly phishing simulation (free tools: GoPhish, KnowBe4 Free)
4. New employees: IT security briefing on day one
5. Document results (attendance lists, test scores)
schulungskonzept.benefit: Trained employees detect 70% more phishing emails. The 2-hour annual investment saves an average of €50,000 in prevented incidents. Mandatory documentation for NIS2 and GDPR audits.
schulungskonzept.nextStep: Plan your first IT security training. Use our training template with agenda, slide suggestions, and attendance documentation.

risikomanagement.name: Risk Management Process
risikomanagement.scenario:
A logistics company invests €200,000 in a next-gen firewall while the biggest threat is an unpatched legacy server in the basement running the entire order processing. Without systematic risk management, budgets are misallocated and real vulnerabilities are overlooked.

Risk management means: knowing where the real dangers lie — and investing there first.
risikomanagement.solution:
1. Create asset inventory: list all critical systems, data, and processes
2. Identify threats: what can go wrong? (Ransomware, outage, data loss)
3. Assess risks: probability × impact (simple matrix)
4. Prioritize measures: address highest risks first
5. Monthly 30-minute workshop: status review and add new risks
risikomanagement.benefit: Systematic risk management saves an average of 40% of IT security budget through better prioritization. It's the core requirement of NIS2, DORA, and BSI IT-Grundschutz — without risk management, no audit passes.
risikomanagement.nextStep: Start with our risk assessment template (Excel). Capture your top 10 risks and prioritize your next measures in 60 minutes.

mfa.name: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
mfa.scenario:
An IT service provider loses access to 200 customer servers because an admin password appears in a data breach. The attacker logs in at night and encrypts all systems. With MFA enabled, the password alone would have been worthless.

81% of all data breaches exploit stolen or weak passwords. MFA stops 99.9% of these attacks.
mfa.solution:
1. Identify critical systems: email, VPN, cloud services, admin access
2. Choose MFA method: authenticator app (recommended), hardware token (high security), SMS (minimum)
3. Plan rollout: admins first, then management, then all employees
4. Define recovery process: what happens with a lost token?
5. Enforcement: configure MFA as mandatory, not optional
mfa.benefit: MFA reduces account compromises by 99.9%. Setup takes 15 minutes per employee and costs nothing with authenticator apps. Mandatory for NIS2-regulated companies.
mfa.nextStep: Enable MFA for your admin accounts today. Start with Microsoft Authenticator or Google Authenticator — both are free.

rbac.name: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
rbac.scenario:
A working student in marketing accidentally has access to all financial data because the permissions of a departed controller were simply copied during onboarding. When his laptop is stolen, all salary data is compromised.

The principle of 'everyone has access to everything' is the most common mistake in SMEs — and the most expensive in an incident.
rbac.solution:
1. Define roles: management, department heads, staff, IT admin, external
2. Per role: which systems and data are actually needed?
3. Create role matrix (use Excel template)
4. Adjust permissions in all systems (AD, cloud, ERP)
5. Quarterly review: are permissions still appropriate?
rbac.benefit: RBAC reduces the attack surface in data breaches by 60%. In an incident, only the data of the respective role is affected, not everything. Mandatory requirement in all IT security standards.
rbac.nextStep: Create your role matrix with our Excel template. Define 5-7 roles and map your systems.

passwort-hygiene.scenario: A tax consultant uses 'Summer2024!' for all client portals. When one portal is hacked, the attacker tries the same password on DATEV, Elster, and the firm's cloud — it works everywhere. 2. Deploy password manager (Bitwarden Business, from €3/user/month)

4. Password rotation: only on suspected compromise (no longer time-based)
5. Admin passwords: 20+ characters, separate password vaults

backup-3-2-1.name: 3-2-1 Backup Strategy
backup-3-2-1.scenario:
A print shop is hit by ransomware. All files encrypted, including the backup on the network share. The only remaining backup set is 8 months old. Result: €45,000 ransom payment and still 3 months of data reconstruction.

The 3-2-1 rule prevents exactly this scenario: 3 copies, 2 different media, 1 copy offsite.
backup-3-2-1.solution:
1. Automatic daily backup to local storage (NAS or server)
2. Second copy on different medium (external hard drive or tape)
3. Third copy offsite: cloud backup or off-site rotation
4. Monthly restore test: can you actually recover?
5. Enable backup encryption and securely store keys
backup-3-2-1.benefit: The 3-2-1 strategy makes you immune to ransomware extortion. Recovery time drops from weeks to hours. Cyber insurers require this strategy as a minimum standard.

verschluesselung.name: Encryption
verschluesselung.scenario:
A field sales representative has their laptop stolen from their car. On it: customer lists, quotes, contracts. Without disk encryption, the thief can simply read all data. Result: mandatory GDPR Art. 33 notification, notification of all affected customers, €15,000 fine.

With BitLocker (Windows) or FileVault (Mac), the laptop would have been worthless.
verschluesselung.solution:
1. Enable disk encryption on all endpoints (BitLocker/FileVault)
2. Encrypt USB drives and external media (BitLocker To Go)
3. Email encryption for sensitive communications (S/MIME or PGP)
4. Database encryption for personal data (TDE)
5. Store recovery keys centrally and securely
verschluesselung.benefit: Encryption turns device loss from catastrophe to inconvenience. With encrypted data, GDPR notification requirements may not apply. Reduces potential fines by up to 90%.
verschluesselung.nextStep: Enable BitLocker on all Windows devices. Your first laptop is protected in 15 minutes.

datenklassifizierung.name: Data Classification

An intern shares an internal price list on LinkedIn because it wasn't marked as confidential. A competitor uses the information to poach customers. Without data classification, employees don't know which information needs what level of protection.

2. Implement labeling system (document footers, email tags)
3. Per level: who may access? How is it stored? How is it shared?
4. Classify existing data (involve department heads)
5. New documents: classification becomes mandatory field
datenklassifizierung.benefit: Data classification prevents accidental data leaks and enables targeted protection measures. Reduces data protection effort by 30% because not everything needs the highest protection level.

patch-management.name: Patch Management
patch-management.scenario:
December 2021: The Log4Shell vulnerability is disclosed. Companies with functioning patch management had the fix deployed within 72 hours. A mid-size retail company without a process took 4 weeks — during which their systems were compromised and customer data stolen.

60% of all successful attacks exploit known vulnerabilities for which patches already exist.
patch-management.solution:
1. Create inventory of all systems and software (automated with WSUS, Intune, or open source)
2. Critical patches: deploy within 72h of release
3. Regular patches: monthly patch cycle (e.g., first Tuesday)
4. Test environment: briefly test patches before production rollout
5. Legacy systems: isolate if patching impossible (network segmentation)
patch-management.benefit: Regular patching prevents 60% of all cyberattacks. Automated patch management saves 10h/week of admin effort. Mandatory requirement for NIS2 and CRA.
patch-management.nextStep: Create your software inventory and define your patch cycle. Start with the most critical systems.

logging-siem.name: Logging & SIEM
logging-siem.scenario:
A company discovers after 6 months that an attacker had access to the mail server. The forensics team asks: 'Show us the logs.' Answer: 'Logs are overwritten after 7 days.' Without logging, it's impossible to determine what was stolen, how the attacker got in, and whether they're still there.

No logs, no evidence. No evidence, no forensics. No forensics, no insurance payout.
logging-siem.solution:
1. Set up central log collection (syslog server, ELK Stack, or Graylog)
2. Minimum logging: logins, errors, changes, network access
3. Log retention: minimum 6 months (NIS2 recommendation: 12 months)
4. Alerting: automatic notification on suspicious patterns
5. Regular log review: check the most important alerts weekly
logging-siem.benefit: Central logging halves the time to detect security incidents (from 207 to ~100 days). Logs are the foundation for forensics, insurance claims, and regulatory reporting.
logging-siem.nextStep: Set up central log collection. Start with login logs from your most critical systems.

schatten-it.name: Shadow IT Management
schatten-it.scenario:
The marketing director installs an AI translator from the internet to create product texts for the French market. The service stores all entered texts on US servers — including unreleased product names and prices. Three months later, the data appears at a competitor.

Meanwhile: a team leader uses a free project management tool. Customer data is uploaded — GDPR violation. The supervisory authority imposes a €20,000 fine.

Shadow IT: software used without IT's knowledge. On average, every company has 5× more apps than officially known.
schatten-it.solution:
1. Inventory: network scan + employee survey — which tools are actually being used?
2. Implement approval process: simple form (name, purpose, data requirements, costs)
3. Management approval for new software installations
4. Security check: VirusTotal scan, privacy review, license check
5. Quarterly review: what new shadow IT has appeared?
6. Maintain whitelist: communicate approved tools for each use case
schatten-it.benefit: Shadow IT management reduces unknown risks by 90%. You save license costs through consolidation (often 20-30% savings). Audit evidence: controlled software usage. Cyber insurers grant up to 15% discount.
schatten-it.nextStep: Conduct a shadow IT inventory. Use our application form and review checklist as templates.
